its 2010 Woman of the Year{{cite news|url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20449594,00.html|newspaper = People|volume = 74|issue = 24|date = December 27, 2010|accessdate =March 7, 2011 | first = Chris|last = Pizzello|pages = 80–81|title = Sandra Bullock: Woman of the Year}} and ranked No. 12 on ''People''{{'}}s Most Beautiful 2011 list.{{cite web|title=PEOPLE's Most Beautiful 2011|url=http://www.people.com/people/package/gallery/0,,20360857_20481337,00.html#20936773|publisher=''People''|accessdate=August 11, 2011|date=April 13, 2011}} In 2010, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine included Bullock in its annual [[TIME 100|''TIME'' 100]] as one of the "Most Influential People in the World."{{cite news|title=The 2010 TIME 100: Sandra bullock|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1984685_1984940_1985519,00.html|accessdate=July 24, 2014|publisher=Time magazine|date=April 29, 2010}} [[File:Sandra Bullock 2011 AA.jpg|thumb|upright|Bullock at the [[83rd Academy Awards]] in 2011]] In 2013, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' named Bullock among the most powerful women in entertainment.{{cite web|title=The Hollywood Reporter's 2013 Women in Entertainment Power 100|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/list/hollywood-reporters-2013-women-entertainment-power-100-664497|website=hollywoodreporter.com|accessdate=July 24, 2014}} In September 2013, Bullock joined other Hollywood legends at the [[TCL Chinese Theatre]] on Hollywood Boulevard by making imprints of her hand- and footprints in cement in the theater's forecourt.{{cite news|title=Sandra Bullock enshrined in Hollywood history|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/sandra-bullock-enshrined-in-hollywood-history/|accessdate=July 25, 2014|work=cbsnews.com|date=September 26, 2013}} In November 2013 it was announced that Bullock was named ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'}}s Entertainer of the Year due to her success with ''The Heat'' and ''Gravity'', which ''Entertainment Weekly'' believed would earn her an Oscar nomination. Bullock shared the title with other distinguished people in the industry such as the creators of the television show ''[[Breaking Bad]]'', [[Matthew McConaughey]], [[Jennifer Lawrence]], "Grumpy Cat" and others.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2013/11/25/entertainers-of-the-year-sandra-bullock|title=This Week's Cover: Our Entertainers of the Year!|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=November 25, 2013}} In 2014, Bullock ranked No. 2 on ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}}s list of most powerful actresses{{cite web|title=Celeb 2014: Most Powerful Actresses|url=http://www.forbes.com/pictures/mfl45ejlfg/sandra-bullock-22/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=July 24, 2014}} and was honored with the Decade of Hotness Award by [[Spike Guys' Choice Awards]].{{cite news|title=Sandra Bullock Receives Decade of Hotness Award From Her 3 Favorite Men|url=https://celebrity.yahoo.com/blogs/yahoo-celebrity/sandra-bullock-receives-decade-of-hotness-award-from-her-3-favorite-men-164725782.html|accessdate=July 25, 2014|publisher=Yahoo|date=June 8, 2014}} In 2015, she was named "[[People (magazine)#People Magazine's 100 Most Beautiful People|The Most Beautiful Woman]]" by ''[[People (magazine)|People]].''{{cite news|title=Sandra Bullock is PEOPLE's World's Most Beautiful Woman|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/04/22/sandra-bullock-people-most-beautiful-woman|accessdate=August 7, 2015|publisher=Entertainment weekly}} == Business ventures == Bullock runs her own production company, Fortis Films. She was an executive producer of the ''[[George Lopez (TV series)|George Lopez]]'' sitcom (co-produced with [[Robert Borden (TV producer)|Robert Borden]]), which garnered a syndication deal that banked her some $10 million .{{cite news|last=Hebert|first=Katie Kuehner|title=And the Award for Best Entrepreneur Goes to Sandra Bullock|url=http://upstart.bizjournals.com/news/wire/2010/03/10/and-the-award-for-best-entrepreneur-goes-to-sandra-bullock.html?page=all|accessdate=August 30, 2013|date=March 10, 2010}} Bullock tried to produce a film based on [[F.X. Toole]]'s short story ''Million-Dollar Baby'' but could not interest the studios in a female boxing drama. The story was eventually adapted and directed by [[Clint Eastwood]] as the [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-winning film, ''[[Million Dollar Baby]]'' (2004).{{cite news|title=Bullock Fires Back At Million Dollar Baby Reports|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news-article/bullock-fires-back-at-million-dollar-baby-reports|accessdate=August 30, 2013|newspaper=[[Contactmusic.com]]|date=March 8, 2005}} Fortis Films also produced ''[[All About Steve]]'' which was released in September 2009. Her father, John Bullock, is the company's CEO,{{cite web|title=Sandra Bullock |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |url=http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800018970/bio |accessdate=February 5, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20061130082742/http://movies.yahoo.com:80/movie/contributor/1800018970/bio |archivedate=November 30, 2006 }} and her sister, Gesine Bullock-Prado, is the former president.{{cite news|title=Bullock's prod'n co. a 'learning experience'|url=http://variety.com/2001/film/news/fortis-fortifies-future-deals-1117794813/|accessdate=October 18, 2014|publisher=Variety}} In November 2006 Bullock founded an [[Austin, Texas]], restaurant, Bess Bistro, located on West 6th Street.{{cite news|title=Drop in Sandra Bullock’s Austin Restaurants |url=http://bristolsquare.myaptportal.com/around-town/drop-in-sandra-bullocks-austin-restaurants/ |accessdate=August 30, 2013 |date=July 25, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20130805072157/http://bristolsquare.myaptportal.com:80/around-town/drop-in-sandra-bullocks-austin-restaurants/ |archivedate=August 5, 2013 }} She later opened another business, Walton's Fancy and Staple, across the street in a building she extensively renovated. Walton's is a bakery, upscale restaurant and floral shop that also offers services including event planning.{{cite news|title=Walton's Fancy and Staple|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/food/2009-07-17/waltons-fancy-and-staple/|accessdate=August 30, 2013|newspaper=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|date=July 17, 2009}} After almost nine years in business, Bess Bistro closed on September 20, 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.kvue.com/story/life/food/2015/09/08/sandra-bullocks-popular-austin-bistro-closing-its-doors/71885108/|title=Sandra Bullock's popular Austin bistro closing its doors|last=Raney|first=Nicole|work=[[KVUE]]|date=September 8, 2015|accessdate=January 24, 2016}} == Personal life == ===Relationships=== Bullock was once engaged to actor [[Tate Donovan]], whom she met while filming ''[[Love Potion No. 9 (film)|Love Potion No. 9]]''; their relationship lasted three years.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20101321,00.html|title=Speeding Bullock}} She previously dated football player [[Troy Aikman]], and actors [[Matthew McConaughey]] and [[Ryan Gosling]].{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2010/03/18/private_drama_plagues_oscar_winner_sandra_bullock/ |title=Private drama plagues Oscar winner Sandra Bullock |work=boston.com |date=March 18, 2010 |accessdate=June 5, 2010 | first=Sandy | last=Cohen}}{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/film/praising-private-ryan/2007/04/25/1177459784728.html |title=Praising Private Ryan |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=April 27, 2007 |accessdate=June 5, 2010}} Bullock married motorcycle builder and ''[[Monster Garage]]'' host [[Jesse James (customizer)|Jesse James]] on July 16, 2005. They first met when Bullock arranged for her ten-year-old [[Godparent|godson]] to meet James as a Christmas present. In November 2009, Bullock and James entered into a custody battle with James' second ex-wife, former pornographic actress [[Janine Lindemulder]], with whom James had a child. Bullock and James subsequently won full legal custody of James' five-year-old daughter.{{cite web |url=http://nationalledger.com/artman/publish/article_272628903.shtml |title=Sandra Bullock Custody Battle |work=National Ledger |date=November 7, 2009 |accessdate=November 19, 2009}} In March 2010, a scandal arose when several women claimed to have had affairs with James during his marriage to Bullock.{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20355742,00.html |title=Jesse James's Alleged Mistress No. 1 to 'Clear the Air' Soon |work=People|date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=March 31, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20355713,00.html |title=Woman No. 3: I 'Made a Mistake' with Jesse James |work=People|date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=March 31, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20354852,00.html |title=A Fourth Woman Alleges Affair with Jesse James |work=People|date=March 31, 2010 |accessdate=March 25, 2010}} Bullock canceled European promotional appearances for ''The Blind Side'' citing "unforeseen personal reasons."{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20352311,00.html |title=Sandra Bullock Pulls Out of London Premiere |work=People|date=March 17, 2010 |accessdate=March 31, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20353810,00.html|title=Without Sandra Bullock, Blind Side's Berlin Premiere Canceled |work=People|date=March 23, 2010 |accessdate=March 31, 2010}} On March 18, 2010, James responded to the rumors of infidelity by issuing a public apology to Bullock. He stated, "The vast majority of the allegations reported are untrue and unfounded" and "Beyond that, I will not dignify these private matters with any further public comment."{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20352642,00.html |title=Jesse James Apologizes to Sandra Bullock and His Children |work=People|date=March 18, 2010 |accessdate=March 18, 2010}} James declared that "There is only one person to blame for this whole situation, and that is me", and asked that his wife and children one day "find it in their hearts to forgive me" for their current "pain and embarrassment." James' publicist subsequently announced on March 30, 2010, that James had checked into a rehab facility "to deal with personal issues" and "save his marriage" to Bullock.{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20355899,00.html |title=Jesse James Checks into Treatment Facility |work=People|date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=March 31, 2010}} However, on April 28, 2010, it was reported that Bullock had filed for divorce{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/package/article/0,,20364464_20364640,00.html |title=EXCLUSIVE: Sandra Bullock Has Filed for Divorce |work=People|date=April 28, 2010 |accessdate=April 28, 2010}} on April 23 in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]].{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/package/article/0,,20364464_20364883,00.html |title=Sandra Bullock's Divorce Likely Won't Be Messy |work=People|date=April 28, 2010 |accessdate=April 28, 2010}} Their divorce was finalized on June 28, 2010, with "conflict of personalities" cited as the reason.{{cite news|author=Abrams, Natalie|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Bullock-James-Divorce-1019990.aspx|title=Sandra Bullock, Jesse James Divorce FInalized|newspaper=[[TV Guide]]|date=June 28, 2010}} As of late 2015, Bullock is dating photographer Bryan Randall.{{cite web|title=Sandra Bullock's Boyfriend Bryan Randall: 5 Things to Know About the Model-Turned-Photographer|url=http://www.people.com/article/sandra-bullock-five-things-to-know-bryan-randall|website=People|accessdate=29 October 2015}} ====Children==== Bullock announced on April 28, 2010, that she had proceeded with plans to adopt a son born in January 2010 in [[New Orleans]].{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/package/article/0,,20364464_20364639,00.html|title=World Exclusive: Meet Sandra Bullock's Baby Boy!|date=April 28, 2010|publisher=People|accessdate=April 28, 2010}} Bullock and James had begun an initial adoption process four months earlier. Bullock's son began living with them in January 2010, but they chose to keep the news private until after the Oscars in March 2010. However, given the couple's separation and then divorce, Bullock continued the adoption of her son Louis Bardo Bullock, as a single parent. In December 2015, Bullock announced that she had adopted a second child, and appeared on the cover of ''People'' magazine with her then {{frac|3|1|2}} year-old new daughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2015/12/02/sandra-bullock-adopts-daughter-laila/76655260/|title=Sandra Bullock adopts second child|date=December 2, 2015|work=USA TODAY}} ===Accidents=== On December 20, 2000, Bullock, the only other passenger, and the two crew all escaped the crash of a chartered business jet uninjured. The pilots were unable to [[Pilot Controlled Lighting|activate the runway lights]] during a night landing at [[Jackson Hole Airport]] due to not using up-to-date [[approach plate]]s, but continued the landing anyway. The aircraft landed in the airport's graded safety area between the runway and parallel taxiway and hit a snowbank. The accident caused a separation of the nose cone and landing gear, partial separation of the right wing, and a bend in the left wing.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/_layouts/ntsb.aviation/brief.aspx?ev_id=20010105X00028|publisher=NTSB|title=Accident Brief DEN01FA030|date=December 2000}} On April 18, 2008, while Bullock was in [[Massachusetts]] shooting the film [[The Proposal (film)|The Proposal]], she and her husband were in an [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] that was hit head-on (driver's side offset) at moderate speed by a [[driving under the influence|drunken driver]]. Vehicle damage was not major and there were no injuries.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/entertainment/15931720/detail.html |title=Sandra Bullock's Car Hit Head-On |publisher=WCVB TV Boston |date=April 19, 2008 |accessdate=April 19, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20080421130109/http://www.thebostonchannel.com:80/entertainment/15931720/detail.html |archivedate=April 21, 2008 }} === Legal matters === In October 2004, Bullock won a multimillion-dollar judgment against Benny Daneshjou, the builder of her [[Lake Austin]], Texas home; the jury ruled the house was uninhabitable. It has since been torn down and rebuilt.{{cite news |first=Amy |last=Schatz |title=Actress Bullock sues over Texas land deal|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-06-24/business/0106240265_1_actress-sandra-bullock-subdivision-lake-austin |accessdate=September 13, 2014 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |agency=[[Knight Ridder|Knight Ridder/Tribune]] |date=June 24, 2001}}{{cite news |title=Actress wins $7m for builder's shoddy work |first=Catherine |last=Elsworth |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1474292/Actress-wins-7m-for-builders-shoddy-work.html|accessdate=September 13, 2014 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |date=October 16, 2004}} Daneshjou and his insurer later settled with Bullock for roughly half the awarded verdict.{{cite web|url=http://www.law360.com/articles/408123/builder-for-sandra-bullock-can-t-revive-malpractice-suit|title=Builder For Sandra Bullock Can't Revive Malpractice Suit|publisher=}} On April 22, 2007, Marcia Diana Valentine was found lying outside James and Bullock's Southern California home in [[Orange County, California|Orange County]]. When James confronted the woman, she ran to her car, got behind the wheel, and tried to run over him. The woman is said to be an obsessed fan of Sandra Bullock.{{cite web|last=Lee |first=Ken |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20036964,00.html |title=Cops: Woman Tried to Kill Sandra Bullock's Husband — Jesse James, Sandra Bullock |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=April 26, 2007 |accessdate=April 18, 2010}} The woman was charged with one felony count each of aggravated assault and stalking. Bullock{{cite news|last=Battistelli|first=L'Oreal|title=Bullock stalker put on notice|url=http://articles.hbindependent.com/2007-05-16/news/hbi-bullock17_1_restraining-sunset-beach-huntington-beach-woman|accessdate=August 30, 2013|newspaper=[[Huntington Beach Independent]] |date=May 16, 2007}} obtained a restraining order to bar Valentine from "contacting or coming near her home, family or work for three years".{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18729381/ |title= Sandra Bullock fan charged with stalking |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=May 17, 2007}} Valentine pleaded not guilty to charges of aggravated assault and stalking.{{cite web |url=http://www.londonnet.co.uk/entertainment/2007/jun/6124_20070613.php |title=Stalker denies attempt to run over Sandra Bullock's husband |publisher=LondonNet |accessdate=April 18, 2010}} She was subsequently convicted of stalking and sentenced to three years' probation.{{cite news |first=Leah |last=Chernikoff |title=Sandra Bullock stalker Marcia Valentine sentenced to three years probation |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2008/11/13/2008-11-13_sandra_bullock_stalker_marcia_valentine_.html| work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |location=New York |date=November 13, 2008 |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} Beginning in 2002, Bullock was also stalked across several states by Thomas James Weldon. In 2003 Bullock obtained a restraining order against him, which was renewed in 2006. After the restraining order expired and Weldon was released from a [[Psychiatric hospital|mental institution]], he again traveled across several states to find Bullock; she then obtained another restraining order.{{cite news |title=Sandra Bullock Gets Restraining Order Against Thomas James Weldon|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/06/sandra-bullock-gets-restr_n_673552.html |accessdate=August 30, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=May 25, 2011}} === Philanthropy === Bullock has been a public supporter of the [[American Red Cross]], having donated $1 million to the organization at least four times. Her first public donation of that amount was to the Red Cross's [[Financial assistance following the September 11, 2001 attacks|Liberty Disaster Relief Fund]]. Three years later, she sent money in [[Humanitarian response to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|response to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunamis]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/SHOWBIZ/Movies/01/03/tsunami.bullock.ap/index.html |publisher=CNN |title=Sandra Bullock donates $1 mil for tsunami |date=January 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20050107041343/http://www.cnn.com:80/2005/SHOWBIZ/Movies/01/03/tsunami.bullock.ap/index.html |archivedate=January 7, 2005 }} In 2010, she donated $1 million to relief efforts in Haiti following the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|Haiti earthquake]], and again donated the same amount following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/SHOWBIZ/celebrity.news.gossip/03/17/bullock.japan.donation/index.html?hpt=T2|publisher=CNN|title=Sandra Bullock sends million for Japan | date=March 18, 2011}} Along with other stars, Bullock did a [[public service announcement]] urging people to sign a petition for clean-up efforts of the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|oil spill]] in the [[Gulf of Mexico]].{{cite news|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebritynews/news/sandra-bullock-urges-fans-to-help-in-gulf-oil-spill-2010207|title=Sandra Bullock Urges Fans to Help in Gulf Oil Spill|publisher=UsMagazine.com}} Bullock backs the Texas non-profit organization The Kindred Life Foundation, Inc., and in late 2008 joined other top celebrities in supporting the work of KLF's founder and CEO Amos Ramirez. At a fundraising gala for the organization, Bullock said, "Amos has led many efforts across our nation that have helped families that are in need. Our country needs more organizations that are committed to the service that Kindred Life is."{{cite news|title=Giving Hearts of Hollywood|url=http://www.listal.com/list/not-just-another-pretty-face|accessdate=June 20, 2013|newspaper=listal.com}} In 2012, Bullock was inducted into the Warren Easton Hall of Fame for her donations to charities, and in 2013 was honored with the [[People's Choice Awards#Special|Favorite Humanitarian Award]] at the [[2013 People's Choice Awards]] for her contributions to New Orleans' [[Warren Easton Charter High School]], which was severely damaged by 2005's [[Hurricane Katrina]].{{cite news|title=Sandra Bullock receives an award for her support to charities|url=http://www.theyarenews.com/eng/2012/5/14/sandra-bullock-receives-award-support-charities-3788.asp|accessdate=July 25, 2014|work=.theyarenews.com|date=May 14, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Sandra Bullock Wins Favorite Humanitarian at 2013 People's Choice Awards|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/sandra-bullock-wins-favorite-humanitarian-at-2013-peoples-choice-awards-2013101|accessdate=July 25, 2014|publisher=US Weekly|date=January 10, '''Emily Yee Chang''' is an American  [[web design]]er, businesswoman, and [[blog]]ger currently living in [[San Francisco]]. She is the co-founder of Ideacodes, a web design consultancy in [[San Francisco]] and the creator of the blog and web resource, EmilyChang.com and eHub.<ref name=japaninterview>[http://japan.cnet.com/column/ehub/ eHub Interviews at CNET Japan]</ref>

==Background==
Chang graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from the [[College of William and Mary]] in 1995 and went on to pursue graduate work in fine art (sculpture, installation, mixed media) at the [[University at Buffalo]]. She graduated with a [[Master of Fine Arts]] degree in 2000. After graduate school, Chang became the first interface and information designer of the Electronic Media Unit at the University at Buffalo. She designed the interfaces and visual designs for all of the university external facing web presence, as well as working on the first student, faculty and alumni portal, known as MyUB. After a period of freelance design consulting, Chang took a position as Web Director at [[Cornell University]], helping launch their first entrepreneur network online.

==Web design==
In 2005, Chang co-founded Ideacodes in San Francisco with long-time partner, Max Kiesler. She has designed, produced and developed [[web sites]], [[blogs]], [[Web portal|portals]], networked communities, and web products for technology companies, educational institutions, startups, non-profits, art and media organizations and organizations such as [[IDEO]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], [[23andMe]], [[Hewlett Packard]], [http://stylehive.com Stylehive], [http://gigaom Gigaom], [http://sixapart.com Six Apart], and the [[Sierra Club]].

Chang is actively involved in [[social media]] and [[open source]] and continues to promote the work of others in the field through her active web 2.0 resource, [http://emilychang.com/go/ehub eHub]. In 2006, [[CNET]] Japan began translating eHub interviews with technology startups and entrepreneurs for a Japanese audience.<ref name=japaninterview/>

Chang is also on the design and user experience advisory board for O'Reilly's Web 2.0 Expo <ref>[http://web20expo.com/ Web 2.0 Expo]</ref> and was an invited judge for the 2008 [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]] Design Achievement Awards.<ref>[http://www.adaaentry.com/judges.php 2008 Adobe Design Achievement Awards]</ref>

==Awards==
In 2009, Chang was nominated for the Cooper Hewitt's National Design Awards in Interaction design. In 2008, Chang was listed among NxE's Fifty Most Influential Female Bloggers,<ref>[http://northxeast.com/general/nxe%e2%80%99s-fifty-most-influential-female-bloggers NxE Fifty Most Influential Female Bloggers]</ref> and acknowledged as one of the Top 50 Women in Technology by Go2Web.<ref>[http://blog.go2web20.net/2008/07/women-in-technology-50-female-bloggers.html Women in Technology]</ref>

Chang's community art project, ADD (analog digital diary) was a finalist in the 2004 SXSW Interactive Awards.<ref>[http://2004.sxsw.com/interactive/web_awards/finalists/2004 SXSW Interactive Awards]</ref> Two University at Buffalo websites launched with Chang's interface designs and won consecutive Council for the Advancement and Support of Education (CASE) grand gold awards: the external eUB website redesign in 2002 and the alumni website in 2003. Her design of a university portal gained distinction as [[IBM]] Best Practices Partner and won the WebDevShare Award for Innovation in Technology in 2001. Her internet work has also garnered Web Marketing Association's best education website, numerous CASE awards, and a [[UCDA]] Gold award.

'''Jenny Craig''' (born '''Genevieve Guidroz''' on August 7, 1932 in [[Berwick, Louisiana]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[weight loss]] guru and founder of [[Jenny Craig, Inc.]] Craig was raised in [[New Orleans]] and married [[Sidney Craig]] in 1979. In 1983, she and her husband created a nutrition, fitness, and weight loss program in Australia and began offering the program in the United States in 1985. The company became a part of [[Nestlé|Nestlé Nutrition]] in 2006.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aPHoTT8Ir7QI&refer=home Nestle Says Jenny Craig Weight-Loss Sales Slowing (Update1)]</ref>

==Philanthropy==
[[File:Jenny and Sid Craig (formal).png|left|thumb|Jenny and Sid Craig, founders of the company]]
Craig is involved in a number of philanthropic causes including the [[San Diego]] Hospice, [[Easter Seals]], United Way/CHAD, the [[Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation]] and Peace At Home's domestic violence prevention program, among others.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wellman|first1=Victoria|title=That's a generous family discount! Jenny Craig sells lavish $9m mansion to her daughter - at $3m less than the asking price|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2082737/Jenny-Craig-sells-lavish-9m-mansion-daughter--3m-asking-price.html|accessdate=26 August 2015|publisher=The Daily Mail|date=January 6, 2012}}</ref> In 1992, Craig and her husband committed $10 million to [[Fresno State University]] for its School of Business and Administrative Services, later renamed the Sid Craig School of Business.<ref>{{cite web|title=We are The Craig School of Business|url=https://www.fresnostate.edu/craig/about/|publisher=Fresno State University|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> In 1996, the couple committed another $10 million to the [[University of San Diego]], $7 million of which was used to build the Jenny Craig Pavilion, a recreation and sports pavilion that was dedicated in October 2000.<ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the Jenny Craig Pavilion|url=https://www.sandiego.edu/jennycraigpavilion/|publisher=University of San Diego|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref>

==Horse racing==
In 1995, Craig and her husband bought a thoroughbred horse ranch and [[horse breeding|breeding]] operation in [[Rancho Santa Fe, California]] formerly owned by sportsman [[Eugene V. Klein|Gene Klein]]. This area is home to the [[Del Mar Thoroughbred Club]]. Craig has been involved in racing and she and her husband have owned a number of successful thoroughbreds. One of their [[Colt (horse)|colt]]s, [[Dr Devious|Dr. Devious]], finished seventh in the 1992 [[Kentucky Derby]] and also raced in [[England]], where he won the 1992 [[Epsom Derby]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wall|first1=Maryjean|title=Dr Devious looms as Derby threat to Arazi's breeze|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-04-29/sports/1992120199_1_derby-dr-devious-arazi|accessdate=26 August 2015|agency=Knight-Ridder News Service|publisher=Baltimore Sun|date=April 29, 1992}}</ref> That same year, their future [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame]] [[filly]] [[Paseana]] won the [[Breeders' Cup Distaff]] at [[Gulfstream Park]]. In 2003, their horse [[Candy Ride]] won six races in a row including the [[Graded stakes race|Grade I]] [[Pacific Classic Stakes]] in which he set a new [[Del Mar Racetrack|Del Mar]] track record for one and a quarter miles. Another Craig owned horse, [[Sidney's Candy]], named after Sid Craig, ran in the [[2010 Kentucky Derby]].<ref>[http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20365574,00.html Jenny Craig's Horse Racing in the Kentucky Derby]</ref>

==Health issues==
In April 1995, while reposing in a favorite armchair and napping, she was startled awake, which caused a strange medical anomaly that mimicked [[Trismus|lockjaw]] but was not, as Craig was eventually able to pry her mouth open. Though there seemed to be no imminent threat, Craig's condition gradually worsened making it difficult for her to speak and eat. Her dentist diagnosed [[temporomandibular joint syndrome]], for which she was referred to a specialist, though to little avail. She was in turn referred to a series of physicians (reportedly 18) all of whom provided various suggestions but ultimately no solution. In the spring of 1998, she was introduced to Dr. Dennis M. Nigro, typically a [[cosmetic surgeon]], who assessed that Craig had suffered atrophying of her mouth muscles. Corrective surgery was provided by installing bioabsorbable screws into her cheeks. She underwent a four-and-a-half-hour operation and another year of [[speech therapy]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Rizzo|first=Monico|title=Painful Silence|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20128085,00.html|publisher=People|accessdate=13 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=King|first=Larry|title=Larry King Live: What Does Jenny Craig Have to Say Now That She Can Speak?|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0103/21/lkl.00.html|accessdate=13 February 2013|newspaper=CNN|date=March 21, 2001}}</ref> Craig has since fully recovered from the debilitating condition.

'''Janice Wendell''' "'''Jan'''" '''Crouch''' (née '''Bethany'''; March 14, 1938 – May 31, 2016) was an American religious broadcaster. Crouch and her husband, [[Paul Crouch|Paul]], founded the [[Trinity Broadcasting Network]] (TBN) in 1973.

==Early life and ministry==
Crouch was the daughter of Reverend and Mrs. Edgar W. Bethany, and grew up in [[Columbus, Georgia]]. Her father served as a pastor in the [[Assemblies of God]] denomination, and was the founding president of [[Southeastern University (Florida)]]. While attending [[Evangel University|Evangel College]] in [[Springfield, Missouri]], Crouch met Paul F. Crouch. They married in 1957, and have two sons, Paul Jr. and Matthew, both of whom are high-ranking officials and program hosts on TBN.  Jan Crouch also had a love for children and was well known in the early days of TBN for child's puppet (a little pink girl in a dress) she called Babushka; so that the color of this puppet and her love for children is often attributed to the fact that she went from wearing her larger than life platinum blonde wigs she wore, to a pink one.  <ref>Matthew "Matt" Crouch narrating https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ByNKEjua4xE June 15, 2016</ref>

==TBN==
===Founding===
In 1973, Paul and Jan Crouch co-founded Trinity Broadcasting Network (TBN). In 1974, TBN purchased its first TV station, KLXA-TV (channel 40, now [[KTBN-TV]]) in Southern California, and began distribution through cable systems in 1978. Under the Crouch family, TBN grew to become the United States' largest Christian television network, offering 24-hour commercial-free programming,<ref name="mediabiz.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabiz.com/thebridge/?release_id=154#1052|title=The BRIDGE – March 2009 – Programming Trends & Top 10s|publisher=Mediabiz.com|accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref><ref name="highbeam.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-102725178.html|title=Heavenly success: TV's largest religious network continues to expand around the world, while adding shows aimed at reaching a much wider audience (30th Anniversary)|publisher=Highbeam.com|accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref> and TBN is currently third largest over-the-air Station Group in the United States (measured as percentage of homes reached), with CBS, Fox, and NBC holding the 4th, 5th and 6th place, according to TV News Check's annual listing of the Top 30 Station Groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/2010/04/07/41240/top-station-groups-stay-the-course|title=Top Station Groups Stay The Course|publisher=TVNewsCheck.com|date=April 7, 2010|accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref> TBN owns and operates five independent TV networks, each of which adheres to a faith-based message, but reaching separate demographics. TBN networks include TBN itself, JUCE TV, TBN Enlace, Smile of a Child, and The Church Channel.{{cn|date=June 2016}}

===Growth of TBN===
Since its founding, Crouch served as TBN's vice president and director of network programming, as well as the director of programming for TBN's affiliated networks, such as the [[Smile of a Child]] children's channel,<ref name="Smile of a Child">{{cite web|url=http://www.smileofachild.tv |title=Smile of A Child TV |publisher=Smile of A Child TV |date= |accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref> the [[JUCE TV]] youth network,<ref name="JUCE TV">http://www.jctv.org/flashindex.php</ref> [[The Church Channel]],<ref name="The Church Channel">{{cite web|url=http://www.thechurchchannel.com |title=A New Digital Network From TBN, the Leader in Religious Television |publisher=The Church Channel |date= |accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref> the [[TBN Enlace USA]] Spanish language network,<ref name="Enlace">http://www.enlace.org/#/inicio/</ref> and others. '''Evelyn de Mille''' (August 1, 1919 – October 31, 2013)<ref>{{cite web|title=Special Collections|url=http://www.ucalgary.ca/lib-old/SpecColl/demille.htm|publisher=ucalgary.ca|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>  is a [[Canada|Canadian]] known for being the first woman in [[Calgary, Alberta]] to own her own stand-alone [[bookstore]] in the city.<ref name=collectionscanada>[http://www.collectionscanada.ca/women/002026-293-e.html Evelyn de Mille], ''[[Library and Archives Canada]]''; URL accessed May 19, 2006.</ref>  
She opened her first bookstore in 1956.<ref name=Brennan>Brennan, Brian, "Evelyn de Mille: Book seller extraordinaire: After 43 years in the trade, retailer is ready to turn the page on an illustrious career Series: International Year of Older Persons",, Calgary Herald. Calgary Herald. Calgary, Alta.: Jun 27, 1999. pg. E.1.FRO</ref>
In 1974 she became the first woman in Canada to found a bookstore chain.<ref name=collectionscanada />

In 1972, she was the first female president of the [[Canadian Booksellers Association]].<ref name=collectionscanada /><ref>[http://cbabook.org/aboutus/CBA.Presidents.1952-2006.pdf CBA Presidents. 1952-2006 (PDF)], ''[http://cbabook.org/ Canadian Booksellers Association]''; URL accessed May 19, 2006.</ref>
In this role, she helped found the ''Bookseller of the Year Awards''.<ref name=collectionscanada />  In 1974 she sold her business to [[W H Smith]], with whom she was involved in a legal dispute.<ref name=collectionscanada />
Evelyn de Mille bought the Owl's Nest bookstore in 1979 and operated it until she sold it 1996.<ref name=collectionscanada />
<ref>Toneguzzi, Mario, "Owl's Nest has an eye for customer service: Bookstore survives arrival of chain stores". ''[[Calgary Herald]]'', August 8, 2005. pg. E.2.</ref>
In 1999, she announced she was retiring permanently from the trade and would sell her last remaining book store, DeMille Technical Books.<ref name=Brennan />  It was later sold to [[McNally Robinson]] bookstore chain.<ref>Parker, David, "Paperwork completed on bookstore", ''Calgary Herald'', January 2, 2002, p. E.3</ref>

In 1998, she was awarded an honorary degree as a Doctor of Laws by the [[University of Calgary]].<ref name=collectionscanada />

DeMille Technical Books operated as part of McNally Robinson's Calgary store from 2002 until McNally Robinson closed the store in 2008.

Under the advice and mentorship of Evelyn DeMille, the assets of DeMille Technical Books were bought by Charlie Perry and the bookstore was re-established under the name DeMille Technical and Business Books Ltd.  The bookstore store continues to serve professionals, trades people and students from its location in downtown Calgary at (Second Level) Standard Life Tower, 639 5th Avenue S.W.  Until a few months before her death Evelyn DeMille was an advocate of independent business and was an advisor to DeMille Books.

Evelyn purchased a page of the Gutenberg bible, and donated it to the University of Calgary, where it now resides in their library.  This entry will be updated with news on her further willed donations and long term support to the University of Calgary.

'''Marguerite Durand''' (January 24, 1864 – March 16, 1936) was a [[France|French]] stage actress, journalist, and a leading [[suffragette]].

==Biography==
Born into a middle-class family, Marguerite Durand was sent to study at a [[Roman Catholic]] convent. After finishing her primary education, she entered the [[Conservatoire de Paris]] before joining the [[Comédie Française]].

In 1888, she gave up her career in the theatre to marry an up-and-coming young lawyer, Georges Laguerre. A friend and follower of the politically ambitious army general [[Georges Boulanger]], her husband introduced her to the world of radical politics and involved her in writing pamphlets for the "Boulangists" movement. However, the marriage was short-lived and in 1891 the couple separated after which Durand took a job writing for ''[[Le Figaro]]'', the leading newspaper of the day. In 1896, the paper sent her to cover the ''Congrès Féministe International'' (International Feminist Congress) ostensibly to write a humorous article. She came away from the event a greatly changed person, so much so that the following year on December 9, 1897 she founded a feminist daily newspaper, ''[[La_Fronde_(newspaper)|La Fronde]]'' to pick up where [[Hubertine Auclert]]'s ''[[La Citoyenne]]'' left off.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=Mary Louise|title=Acting Up: The Feminist Theatrics of Marguerite Durand|journal=French Historical Studies|date=Autumn 1996|volume=19|issue=4|pages=1103–1138|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/286666|doi=10.2307/286666}}</ref>

Durand's newspaper, run exclusively by women, advocated for women's rights, including admission to the [[Bar association]] and the [[École des Beaux-Arts]]. As well, its editorials demanded women be allowed to be named to the [[Legion of Honor]] and  to participate in parliamentary debates. This included, later in 1910, Durand's  attempt to [[Community organizing|organize]] female candidates for the legislative elections. At the 1900 [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|World's Fair]] in Paris, she organized the Congress For The Rights of Women. As well as establishing a summer residence for female journalists in [[Pierrefonds, Oise|Pierrefonds]] in the [[Picardy]] region, Durand turned to activism for working women, helping to organize several [[trade union]]s.

Marguerite Durand, consumed by a passion for the equality of women, was an attractive woman of style and elegance who was famous for walking the streets of Paris with her pet lion she named "Tiger." Instrumental in the establishing of the zoological [[Cimetière des Chiens]] in the Parisian suburb of [[Asnières-sur-Seine]] where her lion was eventually interred, her activism raised the profile of [[feminism in France]] and Europe to an unprecedented level of respectability. Along the way, she compiled an enormous collection of papers that she gave to the government in 1931. The following year, the [[Bibliothèque Marguerite Durand]] opened in Paris and remains to this day one of the best sources in the world for research into feminism and women's history.

Details of Marguerite Durand can be found in the English language in American Professor Mary Louise Roberts' 2002 book, ''Disruptive Acts: The New Woman in Fin-de-Siècle France''. In the French language there is ''Marguerite Durand (1864-1936) "La Fronde" féministe ou "Le Temps"'' by [[Jean Rabaut]] published in 1996.

'''Jeri Ellsworth''' (born 1974) is an American [[entrepreneur]] and [[autodidacticism|autodidact]] [[computer chip]] designer and inventor. Currently the president of [[Technical Illusions]], she became known in 2004 for creating a complete [[Commodore 64]] system on a chip within a [[joystick]], called [[C64 Direct-to-TV]]. That "computer in a joystick" could run 30 video games from the early 1980s and was a very popular Christmas gift, at peak selling over 70,000 units in a single day via the [[QVC]] [[shopping channel]].<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |first=John |last=Markoff |work=[[New York Times]] |date=December 20, 2004 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/20/technology/20joystick.html?ex=1261198800&en=0e285af90f620c58&ei=5090 |title=A Toy with a Story}}</ref>  In late 2014, Ellsworth moved from [[Seattle]] to [[Mountain View, California]] with her team.<ref name="engadget.com" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Takahashi|first1=Dean|title=The DeanBeat: Seattle makes its move to become the capital of virtual reality startups|url=http://venturebeat.com/2014/10/03/the-deanbeat-seattle-makes-its-move-to-become-the-capital-of-virtual-reality-startups/|accessdate=13 June 2015|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=3 October 2014}}</ref>

== Biography ==
Ellsworth was born in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]<ref name="engadget.com"/> and grew up in the towns of [[Dallas, Oregon]] and [[Yamhill, Oregon]], where she was raised by her father, a local [[Mobil Oil|Mobil]] [[filling station]] owner.  As a child, she persuaded her father to let her use a [[Commodore 64]] computer which had been originally purchased for her brother.  She taught herself to program by reading the C64's manuals.  While at high school, she drove [[dirt-track race cars]] with her father, and then began designing new models in his workshop, eventually selling her own custom race cars.  This allowed her to drop out of high school to continue the business.

In 1995, at the age of 21, she decided that she wanted to get away from the race car business,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cLy0mVkoLio |title=Jeri Ellsworth, self-taught engineer, talks about her career|publisher=Youtube.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> and she and a friend started an early [[Intel]] 486-PC-based business, assembling and selling computers.  When she and her partner <!-- who? --> later had a disagreement, Ellsworth opened a separate business in competition.   This new business became a chain of four stores, "Computers Made Easy", selling computer equipment in towns in Oregon.<ref name="Monahan">{{cite news|last=Monahan |first=Matt |date=January 25, 2005 |url=http://159.54.226.83/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050125/BUSINESS/501250320 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060221204134/http://159.54.226.83/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050125/BUSINESS/501250320 |archivedate=2006-02-21| title=Joy of electronics sticks with woman, sparking invention |publisher=''[[Statesman Journal]]'' |accessdate=2011-03-22}}</ref> She ran that chain until selling it in 2000, at which point she moved to [[Walla Walla, Washington]] and attended [[Walla Walla College]], studying circuit design for about a year. She dropped out due to a "cultural mismatch"; Ellsworth said that questioning professors' answers was frowned upon.<ref name="NYT"/>

In 2000, Ellsworth attended her first Commodore exposition, where she unveiled a prototype video expansion for the C64.  This project later evolved to become the CommodoreOne, a.k.a. the [[C-One]], and [[C64 Direct-to-TV|C64-DTV]], and a video on YouTube "Expo Jeri 1st". Ellsworth then began designing computer circuits that mimicked the behavior of her first computer, the Commodore 64.  In 2002, she designed the chip used in the [[C-One]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.c64upgra.de |title=C-One website |publisher=C64upgra.de |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> as an enhanced Commodore 64 which could also emulate other home computers of the early 1980s, including the [[Commodore VIC-20|VIC-20]] and [[Sinclair ZX81]]. She and her fellow developer displayed the C-One at a technology conference, which led to Ellsworth receiving a job offer from Mammoth Toys, which hired her to design the "computer in a chip" for the Commodore-emulating joystick. She began the project in June 2004 and had the project ready to ship by that Christmas.  It sold over a half-million units, in the USA, Europe, and elsewhere.
[[File:2009 Bay Area Maker Faire - Jeri.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Autodidact computer programmer Jeri Ellsworth at a 2009 Bay Area "Maker Faire" conference.]]
From December 2008 until March 2009, Ellsworth hosted a weekly [[webcast]], ''Fatman and Circuit Girl'', together with [[George Sanger (musician)|George Sanger]].<ref name="Webcast1">{{cite web|url=http://makezine.com/2009/04/28/latest-fatman-and-circuit-girl-vids/|title=Latest Fatman and Circuit Girl vids|last1=Branwyn|first1=Gareth|authorlink1=Gareth Branwyn|date=28 April 2009|publisher=[[Make (magazine)|Make]]|accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref><ref name="Webcast2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nycresistor.com/2009/06/25/fatman-and-circuit-girl-jeri-ellesworth-rollerderby-superstar-cover-noahs-ar-rig-at-notacon/|title=Fatman and Circuit Girl (Jeri Ellsworth - Rollerderby Superstar) Cover Noah’s AR Rig at Notacon|last1=Joyce|first1=Matt|date=25 June 2009|publisher=[[NYC Resistor]]|accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref> On May 30, 2009, Ellsworth demonstrated her Home Chip Lab at [[Maker Faire]] Bay Area 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://makerfaire.com/pub/e/2545 |title=Events filled with DIY projects, science, demos, recycling, entertainment, and fun |publisher=Makerfaire.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Ellsworth was named "MacGyver of the Day" on February 25, 2010 by [[Lifehacker]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Torrone | first = Phil | date = February 25, 2010 | url = http://lifehacker.com/5480199/macgyver-of-the-day-electronics-hacker-jeri-ellsworth | title = MacGyver of the Day: Electronics Hacker Jeri Ellsworth | publisher = Lifehacker.com}}</ref>

On December 3, 2010 she released information on how to build a TSA "naked" scanner using repurposed satellite antenna parts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hackaday.com/2010/12/03/make-your-own-tsa-naked-scanner/ |title=Make Your Own TSA "Naked" Scanner |publisher=Hack a Day |date=December 3, 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Ellsworth has published numerous technical articles online regarding subjects as diverse as homemade semiconductors (2009), homemade electroluminescent (EL) displays (2010), EL phosphor manufacture from common ingredients and ways to make transparent EL backplanes without using expensive indium-tin-oxide coated glass.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/06/jeri-ellsworth-turns-an-lcd-into-el.html |title=Make: Online | Jeri Ellsworth turns an LCD into an EL display |publisher=Blog.makezine.com |date=June 11, 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>

Ellsworth was a keynote speaker at the Embedded Systems Conference on May 5, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cLy0mVkoLio|title=Jeri Ellsworth, self-taught engineer, talks about her career|work=YouTube|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> Ellsworth has made significant contributions to ongoing work on [[DIY]] transistors in relation to rapid prototyping as well as thick film fabrication of EL displays using off the shelf chemicals.{{Citation needed|date=April 2014}} In early 2012 Ellsworth and several other notable hardware hackers were hired by [[Valve Corporation]] to work on gaming hardware.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.valvetime.net/threads/im-working-at-valve-on-nextgen-gaming-hardware-jeri-ellsworth.187331/ | title = "I'm working at Valve on nextgen gaming hardware" - Jeri Ellsworth | publisher = valvetime.net }}</ref> Along with several other Valve employees, Ellsworth was dismissed the following year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/jeriellsworth/status/301521067816669184|title=Jeri Ellsworth on Twitter: "Yup.  Got fired today.  Time for new exciting projects."|publisher=Twitter.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/186592/Several_out_of_work_as_Valve_makes_large_decisions_about_its_future.php|title=Gamasutra: Several out of work as Valve makes 'large decisions' about its future|publisher=Gamasutra.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engadget.com/2013/02/13/valve-gabe-newell-layoffs-statement/|title=Engadget: Valve's Gabe Newell on reported layoffs|author=Ben Gilbert|work=Engadget|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>

On May 18, 2013, Ellsworth announced that she had developed an [[augmented reality]] development system named [[castAR]] with fellow ex-Valve engineer Rick Johnson,<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.theverge.com/2013/5/18/4343382/technical-illusions-valve-augmented-reality-glasses-jeri-ellsworth-rick-johnson | title = How two Valve engineers walked away with the company's augmented reality glasses }}</ref> with the blessing of [[Valve Corporation|Valve]]'s [[Gabe Newell]]<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.engadget.com/2013/05/18/cast-ar-hands-on-with-jeri-ellsworth-at-maker-faire-2013 | title = cast AR hands-on with Jeri Ellsworth at Maker Faire 2013|publisher=Engadget.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> and would be funding it via [[Kickstarter]] later in the year. Her start-up company, [[Technical Illusions]], is developing castAR.<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.technicalillusions.com | title = Technical Illusions|publisher=Technicalillusions.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>

Ellsworth later revealed she had been secretly working to make [[castAR]] have "true VR and true AR" in addition to the previously announced projected AR capabilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cc2NQVQK69A|title=CastAR VR / AR System - The 18 Month Story|work=YouTube|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> The castAR Kickstarter,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/technicalillusions/castar-the-most-versatile-ar-and-vr-system|title=castAR: the most versatile AR & VR system|work=Kickstarter|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> launched on October 14, 2013, reached its goal of $400,000 in 56 hours and finished with $1.05 million, 263% of the original goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kicktraq.com/projects/technicalillusions/castar-the-most-versatile-ar-and-vr-system|title=castAR: the most versatile AR & VR system|publisher=Kicktraq.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>

'''Judith "Judy" L. Estrin''' (born 1954 or 1955)<ref name="Forbes 1998 age 43" /> is an Internet pioneer and American business executive.  Former colleague Richard A. Karp credits Estrin as one of the key people in the development of Internet when they worked together with [[Vint Cerf]] on the initial TCP-project at Stanford.<ref name="Karp Interview">{{cite web |url=http://www.wiwiw.org/test/index.php/wiwiw/pioneers/richard_a_karp |title=Interview with Richard A. Karp |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=wiwiw.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/yes-theres-sexism-in-science/article7347256.ece |accessdate=2015-06-24 |title=Yes, there’s sexism in science |website=thehindu.com |date=June 24, 2015}}</ref>

She is now [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of JLabs<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jlabsllc.com/ |title=JLabs |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=jlabsllc.com}}</ref>(formerly called Packet Design Management Company), a privately held company focused on furthering innovation in business, government and non-profit organizations.<ref name="Forbes profile">{{cite web |url=http://www.forbes.com/profile/judith-estrin/ |title=Forbes Profile |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=forbes.com}}</ref> Estrin is the author of "Closing the Innovation Gap: Reigniting the Spark of Creativity in a Global Economy" ([[McGraw-Hill]]; Hardcover, September 2008), a general interest book that challenges national, academic and business leaders to work together to make United States competitive again.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.startup-cafe.fr/en/knowledge/j0QCT4UQBYg/ |title=Diversity in Innovation |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=startup-cafe.fr}}</ref> Estrin is a serial entrepreneur who co-founded eight technology companies.<ref name="Walt Disney Board">{{cite web |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20131223005692/en/Jack-Dorsey-Elected-Walt-Disney-Company-Board |title=Jack Dorsey Elected Walt Disney Company Board |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=businesswire.com |date=December 23, 2013}}</ref>  She was the [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] of [[Cisco Systems]] from 1998 to 2000.<ref name="Forbes profile" /> Estrin served on the boards of [[FedEx]] Corporation (1989–2010),<ref name="Forbes profile" /> [[Rockwell Automation]] and [[Sun Microsystems]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nndb.com/people/927/000161444/ |title=Judith L. Estrin |accessdate=2012-04-04 |website=nndb.com}}</ref> as well as on the Board of Directors of the [[Walt Disney Company]] for fifteen years.<ref name="Walt Disney Board" /> She also serves on the advisory boards of [[Stanford University School of Engineering|Stanford’s School of Engineering]] and [[Bio-X]] interdisciplinary program, and is a member of the [[University of California President’s Science and Innovation Advisory Board]].<ref name="crunchbase">{{cite web |url=http://www.crunchbase.com/person/judy-estrin |title=Judy Estrin Crunchbase Profile |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=crunchbase.com}}</ref>  She also served on the America Compete's Innovation Advisory Board in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.commerce.gov/americacompetes/meet-innovation-advisory-board |title=Meet the Innovation Advisory Board |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=commerce.gov |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120111181416/http://www.commerce.gov/americacompetes/meet-innovation-advisory-board |archivedate=2012-01-11}}</ref>

==Education==
Estrin received a [[bachelor's degree]] in mathematics and computer science from [[UCLA]] and a [[master's degree]] in [[electrical engineering]] from [[Stanford University]] (1977).<ref name="crunchbase" />

==Family==
Estrin's high tech family includes sister [[Deborah Estrin]], a professor of Computer Science <ref>{{cite web |url=http://tech.cornell.edu/deborah-estrin/ |title=Deborah Estrin |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=tech.cornell.edu}}</ref> and parents, [[Thelma Estrin|Thelma]] and [[Gerald Estrin]], who were both computer scientists at UCLA.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cornellsun.com/blog/2012/08/30/an-excellent-match-how-deborah-estrin-first-prof-chosen-for-cornellnyc-tech-was-drawn-to-roosevelt-island/ |title=‘An Excellent Match:’ How Deborah Estrin, First Prof Chosen for CornellNYC Tech, Was Drawn to Roosevelt Island |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=cornellsun.com |date=August 30, 2012}}</ref>  Her son, David Carrico, is also a tech entrepreneur, who founded EvntLive, which later Estrin joined as CEO.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://techcrunch.com/2013/02/06/with-2-3m-from-vint-cerf-more-tech-pioneer-judy-estrin-unveils-evntlive-the-webs-new-interactive-concert-hall/ |title=‘With $2.3M From Vint Cerf & More, Tech Pioneer Judy Estrin Unveils EvntLive, The Web’s New Interactive Concert Hall |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=techcrunch.com |date=February 6, 2013}}</ref>

==Business career==
While at Stanford, Estrin worked with the research group headed by [[Vint Cerf]], a computer science pioneer often called the "Father of the Internet". Cerf's team developed the [[TCP/IP]] specification which forms the underlying technology of the [[Internet]].<ref name="Karp Interview" />

After Stanford she worked at [[Zilog]] Corporation, where she contributed to the design of the [[Zilog Z8|Z8]] and [[Zilog Z8000|Z8000]] microprocessors <ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.computerhistory.org/resources/access/text/Oral_History/102658075.05.01.acc.pdf |title=Oral History Panel on the Development and Promotion  of the Zilog Z8000 Microprocessor |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=archive.computerhistory.org}}</ref> and led the team that developed one of the first commercial [[local area network]] systems
<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.old-computers.com/history/detail.asp?n=52&t=3 |title=Mike Throm's memories of Zilog |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=old-computers.com}}</ref>
called [[Z-net]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=802817&dl=ACM&coll=DL&CFID=417202038&CFTOKEN=41060603 |title=Z-NET a microprocessor based local network by Judy Estrin |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=dl.acm.org |year=1980}}</ref>

In 1981, Estrin co-founded [[Bridge Communications]] — a [[network router]], [[Network bridge|bridges]], and communications [[Server (computing)|servers]] company that went public in 1985 and merged with [[3Com]] in 1987. In 1988 she joined the founding team of [[Network Computing Devices]] (NCD) as Executive Vice President, later becoming President and CEO in 1993.
<ref name="WITI 2002">{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/06-10-2002/0001743960 |title=2002 Women in Technology Hall of Fame |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=prnewswire.com}}</ref>

In 1995, she co-founded [[Precept Software]], Inc., a developer of networking software company, and served as President and CEO until its acquisition by [[Cisco Systems]] in 1998,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/corp_031198.html |title=Cisco Systems Appoints Judith Estrin as Chief Technology Officer,Cisco Systems press release, March 11, 1998 |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=newsroom.cisco.com}}</ref> when she became its CTO and Senior Vice President of Cisco Systems until 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/fspnisapi742a.html |title=Cisco Systems press release, April 3, 2000 |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=newsroom.cisco.com |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20011129023003/http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/fspnisapi742a.html |archivedate=2001-11-29}}</ref>

In 2000, Estrin co-founded Packet Design, LLC, a networking technology company, with her husband [[William N. Carrico, Jr.|Bill Carrico]], with $24 million in funding from the venture firm Foundation Capital and a group of private investors, including Estrin; Carrico; [[James Barksdale]]; [[Bill Joy]], and [[Frank Quattrone]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.forbes.com/2000/06/13/mu2.html |title=Estrin Startup To Address Infrastructure Concerns |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=forbes.com |date=June 13, 2000 |quote=Estrin, 45}}</ref> Packet Design later [[Corporate spin-off|spun out]] three venture backed [[Startup company|start-ups]], including Packet Design, Inc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://layer8solutions.ca/?page_id=76 |title=Packet Design |accessdate=2014-03-04 |website=layer8solutions.ca}}</ref>  She served as Packet Design, LLC’s CEO until it was dissolved, distributing its assets to investors in late 2007.

She served as a member of the boards of directors of The Walt Disney Company from 1998 until 2014, FedEx Corporation from 1989 until 2010, Sun Microsystems from 1995 through 2003 and Rockwell Corporation from 1994 through 1998. In addition, she sits on the advisory councils of Stanford's School of Engineering.

'''Caterina Fake''' (born 13 June 1969, [[Pittsburgh]])<ref name="crunchbaseprof">{{cite web | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/caterina-fake | title=Caterina Fake at CrunchBase | publisher=crunchbase.com | accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="Businessweek 2010">{{cite news |url= http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/feb2010/sb20100222_748785.htm |title= Entrepreneur's Journal: Getting the Startup Equation Right |work= [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date= February 23, 2010 |quote= Caterina Fake, 40}}</ref> is an American [[entrepreneur]] and [[businesswoman]]. She co-founded the websites [[Flickr]] and [[Hunch (website)|Hunch]].<ref name=forbes>{{cite news |url= http://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2012/09/11/caterina-fake-on-launching-her-third-startup-findery/ |title= Caterina Fake on Launching Her Third Startup "Findery" |last= Schawbel |first= Dan |work= [[Forbes]] |date= September 11, 2012}}</ref><ref name=lifehacker>{{cite web |url= http://lifehacker.com/5934812/im-caterina-fake-and-this-is-how-i-work |title= I’m Caterina Fake, and This Is How I Work |last= Miller |first= Tessa |publisher= [[LifeHacker]] |date= August 15, 2012}}</ref>

==Early life and education==
Fake was born in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]],<ref name="RISD" /> to an [[United States|American]] father, and a [[Filipino people|Filipina]] mother who is a naturalized citizen.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://caterina.net/about.html |title= About |publisher= Caterina.net}}</ref><ref name="what you want">{{cite web |url= http://www.wired.com/magazine/2010/07/ff_caterina_fake/ |title= What You Want: Flickr Creator Spins Addictive New Web Service |last= Leonard |first= Devin |date= July 28, 2010 |work= [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate= 2010-07-31}}</ref> As a child, she was not allowed to watch television, and her hobbies included reading poetry and playing classical music.<ref name="hacking education">{{cite web |title=The Techies Who Are Hacking Education by Homeschooling Their Kids |url=http://www.wired.com/2015/02/silicon-valley-home-schooling/ |work=Wired |first=Jason |last=Tanz |date=February 4, 2015}}</ref>

Fake graduated from [[Choate Rosemary Hall]] and attended [[Smith College]]. In 1991 she graduated from [[Vassar College]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] degree in English.<ref name="RISD" /><ref>{{cite web |url= http://vq.vassar.edu/issues/2009/04/features/following-intuition.html |title= Following Intuition: Caterina Fake '91 |first= Bronwen |last= Pardes |work= Vassar, the Alumnae/i Quarterly |date= Fall 2009}}</ref>

==Career==
She started her career as a Lead Designer of Organic Online, a top web development agency, where she worked on web sites for Fortune 500 companies such as [[McDonald's]], [[Kimberly-Clark]], [[Colgate-Palmolive]], [[Levi's]] and [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] - many of them their first online ventures. She served as a Member of the Research Staff at Interval Research.<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=29202831&privcapId=54081498|title=Executive Profile Caterina Fake|publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date =October 29, 2014}}</ref>

In the 1990s, Fake was Art Director at [[Salon.com]], and heavily involved in the development of online community, social software and personal publishing.<ref name="Ludicorp 2003">{{cite web |title= The Team: Creative Director: Caterina Fake |url= http://www.ludicorp.com/team_member.php?id=4 |work= Ludicorp |publisher= Ludicorp Research & Development Ltd |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20031026121434/http://www.ludicorp.com/team_member.php?id=4 |archivedate = 2003-10-26}}</ref> In 1997, she took a job managing the community forums of [[Netscape]].<ref name="what you want" />

In the summer of 2002, she co-founded [[Ludicorp]] in [[Vancouver]] with [[Stewart Butterfield]] and Jason Classon.<ref>{{cite book | title = Founders at Work: Stories of Startups' Early Days | first = Jessica | last = Livingston | year = 2008 | publisher =  Apress | page = 257 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=ktm885vGIXEC&pg=PT264}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= The Ludicorp Team |url= http://www.ludicorp.com/the_team.php |work= Ludicorp |publisher= Ludicorp Research & Development Ltd |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20031026002614/http://www.ludicorp.com/the_team.php |archivedate = 2003-10-26}}</ref> The company developed a [[massively multiplayer online role-playing game]] called ''Game Neverending''. The game did not launch, but Fake and Butterfield started a new product called [[Flickr]] that became one of the world's most popular photosharing websites. Flickr was acquired by [[Yahoo!]] in 2005. Flickr became part of a vanguard of so-called [[Web 2.0]] sites, integrating features such as social networking, community open APIs, tagging, and algorithms that surfaced the most popular content. After the acquisition, Fake took a job at Yahoo!, where she ran the Technology Development group, known for its Hack Yahoo! program and for Brickhouse, a rapid development environment for new products. Fake resigned from Yahoo on June 13, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.techcrunch.com/2008/06/17/flickr-co-founders-join-mass-exodus-from-yahoo/ |title= Flickr Co-founders Join Mass Exodus From Yahoo |last= Arrington |first= Michael |publisher= [[TechCrunch]] |date= June 17, 2008 |accessdate= 2012-03-13}}</ref>

In 2009, Fake co-founded the website [[Hunch (website)|Hunch]] with entrepreneur [[Chris Dixon]]. The site made recommendations to users based on the tastes and opinions that they entered into the system. It launched in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://vator.tv/news/show/2009-06-15-hunch-launches-today |title= Hunch launches today |publisher= [[Vator]] |last= Caceres |first= Chris |date= June 15, 2009 |accessdate= 2010-07-31}}</ref> Hunch was acquired by [[eBay]] for a reported $80 million in November 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/ebay-buys-hunch-for-80-million-2011-11 |title= eBay Buys Chris Dixon's Startup Hunch For $80 Million |work= [[Business Insider]] |last= Yarrow |first= Jay |date= November 21, 2011}}</ref> eBay shut it down in March 2014.

Fake's most recent venture is Findery, which was originally called Pinwheel, and launched in a limited beta in February 2012.<ref name="what you want" /><ref>{{cite web |url= http://caterina.net/2012/02/16/pinwheel-in-private-beta/ |title= Pinwheel! In Private Beta |publisher= Caterina.net |accessdate= March 6, 2012}}</ref> It was renamed to Findery in July 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://marketingland.com/pinwheel-has-a-new-name-findery-17488 |title= Pinwheel Has A New Name: Findery |first=Matt |last=McGee |work=Marketing Land |publisher= Third Door Media |date= July 27, 2012 |accessdate= 2012-08-02}}</ref> The company is headquartered in San Francisco.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/25/business/home-sweet-headquarters-for-an-app-start-up.html |title=Home Sweet Headquarters for an App Start-Up |work=The New York Times |first=Edward |last=Lewine |date=May 24, 2014}}</ref>

==Memberships==
Fake joined the board of directors of [[Creative Commons]] in August 2008,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/8953|title=Flickr Cofounder Caterina Fake Joins Creative Commons Board |last=Steuer |first=Eric |date= August 25, 2008 |publisher= Creative Commons |accessdate= 2008-09-08}}</ref> and is Chairman of the Board of [[Etsy]]. She is a Founder Partner at Founder Collective, and advises many startups and new businesses.

==Awards and honors==
Fake has won many awards, including [[BusinessWeek]]'s Best Leaders of 2005,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://images.businessweek.com/ss/05/12/bestleaders/source/19.htm |title= Best Leaders: Entrepreneurs - Stewart Butterfield & Caterina Fake - Flickr |work= [[BusinessWeek]] |accessdate= 2010-07-31}}</ref> [[Forbes]] 2005 eGang, [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'s Fast 50, and [[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring]]'s 20 Entrepreneurs under 35. In 2006, she was named to the Time 100, [[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]]'s list of the world's 100 most influential people, appearing on the cover of Newsweek that same year.

In May 2009 she received an Honorary Doctorate from the [[Rhode Island School of Design]].<ref name="RISD">{{cite web |url= http://www.risd.edu/commencement_hondegrees.cfm |title= Commencement: Honorary degrees |publisher= [[Rhode Island School of Design]] |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090418204442/http://www.risd.edu/commencement_hondegrees.cfm |archivedate= April 18, 2009}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Fake was married to [[Stewart Butterfield]], her Flickr co-founder, from 2001<ref>{{cite web |url= http://money.cnn.com/2007/09/11/news/companies/startup_couples.biz2/ |title= Love, e-company style |last= Chatterjee |first= Pia |work= Business 2.0 Magazine |publisher= [[CNN Money]] |date= September 12, 2007}}</ref> to 2007.<ref name="what you want" /> They had one daughter together, in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://gawker.com/277694/silicon-valleys-baby-boom |title= Silicon Valley’s baby boom |last= Thomas |first= Owen |work= [[Gawker]] |date= July 12, 2007}}</ref> As of 2015, Fake is in a relationship with [[Jaiku]] co-founder [[Jyri Engeström]], and the couple has three children between them.<ref name="hacking education" />

Fake currently lives in [[San Francisco]], [[California]] and [[New York City]].

'''Françoise Giroud''', born '''France Gourdji'''  (21 September 1916 in [[Lausanne]], Switzerland and not in Geneva  as often written – 19 January 2003 in [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]]) was a French [[journalist]], [[screenwriter]], writer and politician.

==Biography==
Giroud was born to immigrant Sephardic Turkish Jewish parents; her father was Salih Gourdji, Director of the Agence Télégraphique Ottomane in Geneva.<ref name="Independent">[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/franccediloise-giroud-746225.html Obituary] in the London ''Independent'' (published 21 January 2003)</ref>
She did not graduate from university.<ref name="Milwaukee">[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-6166816.html Obituary], ''Milwaukee Journal Sentinel'', published 20 January 2003</ref>  She married and had two children, a son (who predeceased her) and a daughter.<ref name="Independent"/><ref>[http://questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=Lz3hlSnh/THddMHpp Questia website], accessed 24 December 2009</ref>

==Career==
Giroud's work in cinema began with director [[Marc Allégret]] as a script-girl on his 1932 version of [[Marcel Pagnol]]'s ''Fanny''.  In 1936 she worked with [[Jean Renoir]] on the set of ''[[Grand Illusion (film)|La Grande Illusion]]''.  She later wrote screenplays, eventually completed 30 full-length books (both fiction and non-fiction), and wrote newspaper columns.<ref>[http://britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/914334/Francoise-Giroud "Françoise Giroud"] ''Britannica'' online], accessed 24 December 2009</ref>  She was the editor of [[Elle (magazine)|''Elle'']] magazine from 1946 (shortly after it was founded) until 1953, when she and Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber founded the French newsmagazine ''[[L'Express (France)|L'Express]]''.  She edited ''L'Express'' until 1971, then was its director until 1974, when she was asked to participate in the French national government.

From 1984 to 1988 Giroud was president of Action Internationale contre la Faim. From 1989 to 1991 she was president of a commission to improve cinema-ticket sales. She was a literary critic on ''[[Le Journal du Dimanche]]'', and she contributed a weekly column to ''[[Le Nouvel Observateur]]'' from 1983 until her death.  She died at the [[American Hospital of Paris]] while being treated for a head wound incurred in a fall.<ref name="Milwaukee"/>

==Political career==
In 1974 French President [[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing]] nominated Giroud to the position of [[Ministry of Women's Affairs (France)|Secrétaire d'État à la Condition féminine]], which she held from 16 July 1974 until 27 August 1976, when she was appointed to the position of [[Minister of Culture (France)|Ministre de la Culture]].  She remained in that position until March 1977, for a total service of 32 months, serving in the cabinets of [[Jacques Chirac]] and [[Raymond Barre]].  She was a member of the [[Radical Party (France)|Radical Party]], and on the election documents she listed her profession as "journaliste".<ref>Christine Bard, [http://www.histoire-politique.fr/index.php?numero=01&rub=dossier&item=7 Les premières femmes au Gouvernement (France, 1936-1981)], ''[[Histoire@Politique]]'', n°1, May–June 2007 {{fr icon}}</ref>

==Other activities==
Giroud received the [[Légion d'honneur]].  She managed [[Action Against Hunger|ACF]], a Nobel-winning charity, from 1984 to 1988.<ref name="Independent"/><ref>[http://www.franceinlondon.co.uk/en-Article-74-The-Biography-of-Francoise-Giroud-by-COckrent-Culture-.html "France In London" website], review of FG Biography by Christine Ockrent</ref>

Giroud often voiced her goal: to get France "out of its rut".  She said that Americans had the right idea; they didn't get into a rut.  On her first visit to New York City soon after World War II ended, she had been struck by "the degree of optimism, the exhilaration" she had found there. That view stayed with her: "There is a strength in the United States that we in Europe constantly tend to underestimate."<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-96900279.html Obituary] ''The Economist'' (25 January 2003)</ref>

Well into her 80s, Giroud appeared on French television, in the program ''100 Ans'' (which explores the possibility of living to be a hundred).  She appeared with face and hands bandaged from a fall just before the filming began.  She was asked to recommend the diet that would provide for longevity; she replied "chopped steak and salads".  She tried (and failed) to peel an apple with her bandaged hands; when she was unable, she burst out laughing.

Several laudatory newspaper articles about her death mentioned her sparkling sense of humor.

A special issue of ''L'Éxpress'' covered Giroud's death.  It stated:
:Women everywhere have lost something.  Ms. Giroud defended them so intelligently and so strongly.<ref>[http://sen.parl.gc.ca/lpepin/index.asp?PgId=903&1=E The Honorable Lucie Pépin, Senator]</ref>

'''Anne Margaret Glover''', [[CBE]] (born 6 February 1954),<ref>{{cite web|title=Anne Glover|url=http://www.clarealumni.com/s/845/1col.aspx?sid=845&gid=1&pgid=599|publisher=[[Clare College, Cambridge]]|accessdate=7 January 2012}}</ref> is [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and co-founder of Amadeus Capital Partners, a [[venture capital]] firm that invests in European high-technology companies. Prior to founding Amadeus in 1997, she was with Apax Partners & Company Ventures, where she was a member of the investment team. She also has experience as a [[Angel investor|business angel]], investing in UK-based [[information technology]] start-ups. Glover has also had significant operating experience with [[Virtuality Group]] plc, where she was [[Chief operating officer|COO]] of the [[virtual reality]] peripherals company.

Glover also was a manager and consultant with [[Bain (consulting)|Bain & Company]] in Boston for five years.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=136902&privcapId=90151|title=Anne Glover: Executive Profile & Biography - Businessweek|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> Earlier in her career, she held a variety of management positions with [[Cummins|Cummins Engine]].<ref name=":0" />

She is a former chairman of the British Venture Capital Association (BVCA), which represents approximately 165 UK-based [[private equity]] and venture capital firms. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cityam.com/article/1402624479/evca-names-glover-chairman|title=EVCA names Anne Glover as chairman|date=2014-06-13|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>She is also on the [[Technology Strategy Board]] of the UK's [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ageing.ox.ac.uk/news/prime-minister-david-cameron-appoints-prof-harper-council-science-and-technology|title=Prime Minister David Cameron appoints Prof Harper to the Council for Science and Technology|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>

Glover earned a master's degree in management from [[Yale School of Management]] and a master's degree in [[metallurgy]] and [[materials science]] from [[Clare College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://alumni.som.yale.edu/news/2014/06/anne-glover-78-named-european-private-equity-and-venture-capital-association-chairman|title=Anne Glover '78 Named European Private Equity and Venture Capital Association Chairman {{!}} Yale SOM Alumni|website=alumni.som.yale.edu|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>

Glover was awarded a [[CBE]] in the 2006 Queen's Birthday Honours list "for services to business".

She was elected Chair of the European Private Equity and Venture Capital Association in June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nicholson|first1=Lynn|title=EVCA announces 2014-2015 Chairman|url=http://www.evca.eu/news-opinion/newsroom/press-releases/evca-new-chairman/|website=European Private Equity and Venture Capital Association|publisher=EVCA|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref>

Anne Glover along with Dervilla Mitchell, Professor Sarah Harper, Professor Fiona Murray and Professor Philip Bond was appointed to the [[Council for Science and Technology]] in March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Prime Ministers Office|title=Prime Minister appoints new members of the Council for Science and Technology|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-appoints-new-members-of-the-council-for-science-and-technology|website=gov.uk|accessdate=23 June 2014}}</ref>
